text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with bolognese sauce that's right
this video recipe is dedicated to the
late great marchello hasan who for those
you that don't know was basically the
julia child of italian cuisine and this
amazing meat sauce was one of her
signature recipes
although i'm pretty sure she stole the
recipe from my grandmother but since i
can't prove anything we're just going to
move on and we're going to start by
sweating our aromatic vegetables so in
our sauce pot we have a little bit of
olive oil and a little bit of butter and
we're going to put that over medium heat
and as soon as the butter melts we're
going to go ahead and throw in some
finely diced onions celery and carrots
and we'll give that a stir with our
wooden spoon
the official bolognese sauce stirring
instrument accept no substitutes we'll
also throw in a big pinch of salt to
help draw out that water and like i said
we're just going to cook that stirring
until they turn translucent and they're
going to go from looking like this to
looking like this at that point we're
going to go ahead and throw in our beef
and i'm using ground beef i got some
beautiful local grass-fed beef and we're
going to throw that in we're going to
keep it right on medium heat and what
we're going to do is we're going to cook
this for about five minutes stirring
constantly breaking up that meet with
our wooden spoon as we stir and because
we have a fair amount of those soft
sweated vegetables this is going to be
very easy to get this ground beef in
very small pieces and when we have it
down to basically crumbles we're going
to go ahead and add our seasoning which
is going to be very straightforward
we're going to put in some salt some
freshly ground black pepper and a little
touch of cayenne and then last but not
least some freshly grated nutmeg and I
don't care if you don't like it you're
gonna add this this is a subtle but very
important part of the flavor profile so
do not skip the Nutmeg alright so we're
gonna go ahead and stir in the seasoning
and we're ready for the next ingredient
which is the milk yes one of the secret
ingredients in this meat sauce is milk
and I'm using 2% the low fat milk which
I assume will let us classify this
recipe as low fat but we're going to
stir in our milk that's going to come up
to a simmer and we're going to cook that
until most of the milk simmers out and I
said most of do not be a hero and try to
reduce this completely you burn that
milk onto the bottom you are starting
over and by starting over I mean you
know ordering pizza alright so like I
said we're going to simmer that until
most of the milk is evaporated and it
looks like that
at which point we're going to add the
next addition of liquid the white wine
and a lot of it I'm going to raise my
heat up to
geom hi we're going to bring this to a
simmer and then do the exact same thing
we're going to cook this stirring until
most of the wine is evaporated and we're
back to that kind of meat paste
consistency and just like the milk if
you go down too far the wine will burn
so be very careful all right so let that
simmer until the wine reduces and once
we've simmered off that wine and it
looks like that we're ready for our
tomatoes and I'm going to use a can of
san marzano plum tomatoes these are
packed whole so all we're going to do is
throw those in a bowl and use our clean
bare hand to crush them into a puree and
yes you could use a food mill or a food
processor but then you wouldn't be able
to feel what I'm feeling and I like it
when you feel it I'm feeling so we're
going to crush those Tomatoes we're
going to pour them into our pot we're
also going to rinse out the can with a
couple cups of water and add that in and
then all we need to do here is let this
come up to a simmer which I'm going to
do on medium-high heat
and it's going to look like that but
that's too high so what we're going to
do is give it a stir and we're going to
back that heat down to low and we're
going to keep adjusting it to maintain
that perfect very very very gentle
simmer and then all we're going to do is
let this simmer just like that for a
brief four to six hour period or until
it cooks down into a thick sauce that's
just too good to be true and you could
probably get away with three hours but
the longer the better so this is just
one of those sauces it needs to simmer
for a really long time on low heat and
while this simmers if you want you can
spoon off a little of the fat that comes
to the top but that's between you and
your cardiologist I did skim off most of
it and as it cooks that liquids going to
slowly evaporate the flavors are going
to concentrate the meats going to get
unbelievably tender and about five hours
later it should look something like this
or at least that's what mine look like
and for whatever reason if this reduces
too quickly and it's getting too thick
and dry and you want to cook it a little
longer just keep adding splashes of
water as needed and obviously it's up to
you on how thick you want to make this
you can keep cooking this and make it
even thicker but for me that's the
perfect texture right there and at that
point you can turn off the heat because
your bolognese sauce is done although we
really should taste it in just a
seasoning you may need more salt maybe a
little pinch of pepper but taste and
adjust to your liking
you are the Patrick Swayze of your
Bolognese and not go Swayze point break
Swayze so I tasted an adjusted mine and
that point I was so ready to enjoy this
with some pasta now traditionally this
is served with tagliatelle although I'm
going to use these meze rigatoni which I
think are the absolute perfect shape for
this sauce you're going to see why very
shortly and you know I like to heat my
pasta with the sauce before I plate it
this sausage is too special to just
unceremoniously ladle over the top of
some naked pasta it's not a good look so
I mixed my rigatoni with my sauce we're
going to plate that up maybe a little
parmesan or a little pecorino romano on
top maybe just a touch of fresh parsley
and that's it a fairly classic version
of bolognese sauce just one of the great
plates of food in the history of the
world and you can see here why I like
these messy rigatoni so much you can see
how that sauce and all those little
pieces of meat get inside the pasta I
mean that's perfect sauce to pasta
distribution right there and the flavor
just beyond description
so anyway like I said this was my take
on marchello Hassan's famous bolognese
sauce and if you're not familiar with
her work do yourself a favor
check her out online and see why she was
such a huge influence so I really do
hope you give this a try head over to
